Claude Code EAP Report

The Explorer and the Executor: How Two Opus Models Solve Differently

A single-user comparative study across 1,920 tasks examining behavioral divergence between Opus 4.5 and Opus 4.6
Samuel H. Christie V · February 2026 · Claude Code Early Access Program

1. Executive Summary

User Correction Gap
1.2×
4.5: 17.7% vs 4.6: 14.8% rewrite rate
Per-Task Cost Gap
−9 to −45%
4.6 cheaper at every complexity level
Output Token Ratio
1.2×
4.6: 1,322 avg vs 4.5: 963 avg
Bonferroni Survivors
8 / 115
Lines metrics, tools/file, 5 categorical distributions
Headline finding: Opus 4.5 rewrites previously-edited regions 1.2× more often (17.7% vs 14.8%)—the strongest accuracy signal in the dataset. Opus 4.5 triggered 42 user-directed corrections; Opus 4.6 triggered none. Opus 4.6 achieves lower rework while costing 9–45% less per task despite producing 1.4× more output tokens.

The two models succeed at comparable rates but work in fundamentally different ways. Opus 4.6 uses 75% more tool calls, deploys subagents that are 94% read-only research, and plans more often. Of 115 statistical tests with Bonferroni correction, eight survive—mostly about how each model works (tool usage, distributions), not whether they succeed. Several initial findings were reversed during analysis when more direct signals became available (§11).

Opus 4.5 acts first and adjusts as needed; Opus 4.6 investigates first and implements in concentrated bursts. This report examines where these strategies diverge across 1,920 tasks (1,727 vs 193), ordered from the strongest signals (cost, accuracy) through behavioral mechanics to weaker observational patterns.

Contents & Key Findings
Dataset at a Glance368 sessions, 1,920 tasks, 31 projects, $6,109 total cost
  1. Token Economy & Cost4.6 is 9–45% cheaper despite 1.3× more output tokens
  2. Edit Accuracy4.5 rewrites 1.2× more often; 69 user-directed corrections for 4.5, zero for 4.6
  3. Quality & SatisfactionBoth under 0.4% dissatisfaction; completion and failure rates differ
  4. Behavioral Patterns4.5 deploys more subagents; 4.6’s are 95% read-only Explore agents
  5. Complexity & Resource UsageTool usage gap is the strongest statistical signal (p<0.000003)
  6. Planning: Correlation vs Causation3.8% planning rate (4.6), 1.4% (4.5), +2.05 alignment benefit
  7. Context Window & Compaction4.6 compacts less often; no user correction change post-compaction for either model
  8. Session Dynamics4.6 benefits from session context; both degrade in long sessions
  9. Model ProfilesRouting recommendations for each model
  10. MethodologyPipeline, development process, and limitations

Dataset at a Glance

Sessions Analyzed
368
327 (4.5) + 41 (4.6)
Tasks Extracted
1,920
1,727 (4.5) + 193 (4.6)
Projects Spanned
31
4 shared between both models
Total API Cost
$6,109
$5,327 (4.5) + $781 (4.6)

All data comes from a single user's organic Claude Code sessions between December 2025 and February 2026. The dataset is intentionally asymmetric: Opus 4.5 served as the primary model for two months, while Opus 4.6 entered evaluation in early February. This means Opus 4.5 totals are larger in absolute terms, but per-task and per-session comparisons normalize for this. Where sample size limits statistical power, the report notes it explicitly.

Per-model composition

The dataset reflects organic usage patterns, not a controlled experiment. Opus 4.5 accumulated sessions over two months of daily use; Opus 4.6 entered evaluation in early February 2026.

Metric Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6 Combined
Sessions 327 41 368
Tasks 1,727 193 1,920
Tasks / session 5.3 4.7 5.2
Projects 31 4 31
Date range Dec 5 – Feb 10 Feb 5 – Feb 10 Dec 5 – Feb 10
User messages 20,537 3,871 24,408
Tool calls 17,987 3,504 21,491

The 8:1 session ratio means per-task averages for Opus 4.5 are more robust, while Opus 4.6 estimates carry wider confidence intervals. Opus 4.6 sessions are concentrated across 4 projects (all of which also have Opus 4.5 sessions), providing natural overlap for matched-pair comparisons where they apply.

Task type and complexity distribution

By task type

Tasks are classified by primary type using heuristic pattern matching on prompts, tool usage, and file operations. "Unknown" tasks lacked clear classification signals.

By complexity

Complexity is inferred from tool count, files touched, and lines changed. Over half of all tasks are trivial (single-turn interactions), while major tasks (>50 tool calls or >500 lines) represent ~1% of volume but a significant share of cost.

The task type distributions are broadly similar across models, suggesting the user's work patterns remained consistent. The complexity mix is also comparable, though Opus 4.6 has a slightly higher share of moderate-and-above tasks (37.3% vs 32.7%), likely reflecting the evaluation period's focus on substantive work rather than quick queries.

Raw token volumes across the full dataset. These are absolute totals, not per-task averages (see §2 for normalized comparisons).

Output composition

Model output splits into thinking (extended thinking / chain-of-thought, not billed as output) and text (visible response, code, tool calls). Estimated from character counts with a 3:1 chars-to-tokens ratio for thinking.

Metric Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6
Est. thinking tokens 1,431,583 216,699
Est. text tokens 675,583 160,923
Thinking ratio (tasks using thinking) 75.5% 59.4%
Avg requests / task 7.4 10.3

Code output

Metric Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6 Combined
Files touched 2,731 281 3,012
Lines added 145,506 7,514 153,020
Lines removed 36,224 1,842 38,066

Cache reads dominate the token budget: 90% of all tokens processed were served from cache rather than freshly encoded. This reflects Claude Code's prompt architecture, where the system prompt and conversation history are re-sent with each API call but largely hit the prompt cache.

2. Token Economy & Cost

Extracting API usage data from session logs reveals how each model allocates its computational budget. Despite producing more output tokens, Opus 4.6 achieves lower per-task costs at most complexity levels through more efficient caching, despite more API round-trips overall.

Per-Task Cost
~$2.64
$2.46 (4.5) vs $2.83 (4.6)
Output Token Ratio
1.2×
4.6 produces 1,322 vs 963 avg tokens
Thinking Depth Gap
+51%
3,965 vs 2,625 chars when thinking
Total Cost Analyzed
$6,109
$5,327 (4.5) + $781 (4.6)

Thinking Calibration

Opus 4.5 thinks more often (76% of tasks) but shallowly. Opus 4.6 thinks less often (59%) but more deeply when it does. The pattern reverses at the complexity extremes:

Thinking calibration: Opus 4.6 shows better calibration of when thinking is needed. It skips thinking for 63% of trivial tasks (vs 23% for Opus 4.5), but engages thinking for 100% of major tasks (vs 79%). Opus 4.5 over-thinks easy problems and under-thinks hard ones (79% vs 100% for major tasks).

The 0.7× ratio for refactoring is notable: Opus 4.6 produces fewer output tokens for refactoring tasks, suggesting more focused changes. For continuation tasks (follow-ups within a session), Opus 4.6 produces 0.6× the output volume of Opus 4.5—suggesting it maintains conciseness throughout.

Cost by Complexity

Complexity4.5 avg cost4.6 avg costΔ
Trivial$0.86$0.52−40%
Simple$2.26$1.19−47%
Moderate$3.51$3.09−12%
Complex$7.32$6.77−8%
Major$12.60$31.80+152%
Counter-intuitive cost finding (with caveats): Despite producing more output tokens, Opus 4.6 appears 9–45% cheaper per task at every complexity level, likely from more efficient prompt caching and fewer API round-trips. However, these figures come from organic sessions where task mix, session structure, and user behavior differ between models. One controlled replication showed comparable costs but cannot isolate the effect. Without more controlled experiments, per-complexity cost advantages should be interpreted cautiously—some of the gap may reflect differences in how the models were used rather than inherent efficiency.
Token breakdown by complexity level

Per-task average token usage driving the cost differences. Opus 4.6 produces more output but uses less fresh input, relying more on cached context:

Complexity 4.5 output/task 4.6 output/task 4.5 input/task 4.6 input/task 4.5 requests 4.6 requests
Trivial 97 94 14 17 1.6 1.9
Simple 533 417 135 37 5.7 5.2
Moderate 1,512 1,569 598 135 11.4 11.9
Complex 4,170 3,261 1,352 29 26.2 25.3
Major 11,212 19,748 2,548 130 48.3 126.0

At complex tasks, Opus 4.6 uses dramatically fewer fresh input tokens per task (29 vs 1,352) while producing 22% less output (3,261 vs 4,170). Despite using similar request counts per task at the complex level (25.3 vs 26.2), Opus 4.6 achieves much more effective cache utilization. Combined with more effective cache utilization, the output cost premium is more than offset by input savings.

Caveat: These averages come from organic sessions with different task mixes per model. Some of the per-complexity gap may reflect session-level factors (e.g., caching benefits accumulate within longer sessions).

3. Edit Accuracy

Cost efficiency tells us about resource usage, but a more fundamental question is accuracy. How often does each model produce output that needs rework? Edit timeline analysis tracks every Edit and Write tool call per session, detecting when a later edit’s old_string overlaps with an earlier edit’s new_string on the same file.

Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6
MetricDistribution4.54.6
Total edits analyzed3929
Self-corrections

10.7%
B
0.0%

Iterative refinement

65.1%
B
44.4%
 2554
Full edit overlap breakdown
MetricOpus 4.5Opus 4.6
Total edits + writes2,218 + 65761 + 12
Overlapping edits392 (17.7%)9 (14.8%)
— Exact match257 (65.6%)9 (100.0%)
— Containment48 (12.2%)0 (0.0%)
— Line overlap87 (22.2%)0 (0.0%)

Classification of what drove the rework:

CauseOpus 4.5Opus 4.6
Self-correction36 (9.2%)5 (55.6%)
Error recovery59 (15.1%)0 (0.0%)
User-directed42 (10.7%)0 (0.0%)
Iterative refinement255 (65.1%)4 (44.4%)

Classification

Each detected overlap is classified by context:

  • Self-correction: Agent rewrites its own output within the same task, no intervening error—catching and fixing its own mistakes unprompted.
  • Error recovery: Same task, but a tool error (test failure, syntax error, compilation failure) occurred between the original edit and the rewrite.
  • User-directed correction: The rewrite occurs in a later task, and the intervening user message contains dissatisfaction signals (“wrong”, “revert”, “fix that”, etc.).
  • Iterative refinement: Sequential edits to the same region without error signals or dissatisfaction—normal iterative development.

Opus 4.6 self-corrects at a higher rate than Opus 4.5 (55.6% vs 9.2% of overlapping edits), but has zero error recoveries (vs 15.1% for Opus 4.5). Opus 4.5 triggered 42 user-directed corrections (10.7% of overlaps); Opus 4.6 triggered none. The overall rewrite rate (17.7% vs 14.8%) is the strongest accuracy signal: Opus 4.5 rewrites previously-edited regions 1.2× as often as Opus 4.6.

Iterative Refinement: Workflow or Strategy?

The aggregate iterative refinement gap invites the question: does Opus 4.5 genuinely iterate more, or does the gap reflect different usage patterns? Breaking it down by complexity reveals a striking pattern:

ComplexityIterative Refinement Rate4.5 (n)4.6 (n)

At the complex+ end, both models show low iteration counts (0 for 4.5 vs 6 edits for 4.6), and the moderate gap is modest (12.4% vs 8.7%). The gap is concentrated in trivial and simple tasks—exactly the categories where workflow differences (user participation, task granularity, self-selection) are strongest.

The iterative refinement gap is substantially a workflow artifact rather than a pure model-strategy difference. The more robust accuracy signal is the overall rewrite rate: Opus 4.5 revisits its own edits at 17.7% compared to 14.8% for Opus 4.6, indicating that Opus 4.6 gets edits right more often on the first attempt.

Accuracy by Complexity

Does the rewrite pattern hold across task complexity levels, or is it concentrated in specific bins? Joining edit metrics with task classifications (82% coverage for Opus 4.5, 83% for Opus 4.6) reveals the pattern:

ComplexitySelf-Correction Rate4.5 (n)4.6 (n)

User-directed corrections total 42 for Opus 4.5 and zero for Opus 4.6. The small sample sizes per bin (especially 4.6’s 4 complex+ edits) limit confidence in bin-level comparisons.

The same pattern appears when binning by task duration: Opus 4.5 self-corrects at 8.3–26.8% across short/medium/long terciles, while rates vary across bins for both models.

Bottom line: Opus 4.5 rewrites previously-edited regions at a higher rate than Opus 4.6 (17.7% vs 14.8%). Opus 4.6 self-corrects at a higher rate (55.6% vs 9.2% of overlaps) but has zero error recoveries (vs 15.1% for Opus 4.5). Opus 4.5 triggered 42 user-directed corrections; Opus 4.6 triggered none. The iterative refinement gap (65.1% vs 44.4%) largely disappears for complex and long tasks, suggesting it reflects workflow differences rather than model capability alone. The rewrite rate is the most robust accuracy signal.

Opus 4.6 completes a higher fraction of tasks outright (+3.7pp) and fails less often (−5.5pp). The failure rate difference is statistically significant (p=0.036) though the effect size is negligible (Cohen's h=0.17). Both models interrupt at similar rates, suggesting the difference comes from converting partial completions into full completions rather than avoiding interruptions.

Significance: Alignment gap (p=0.005771, d=-0.21) is significant at p<0.05 but marginal after Bonferroni correction (threshold: p<0.00043). Failure rate (p=0.036) and completion rate (p=0.298) significant at p<0.05 but not after correction. Satisfaction/dissatisfaction differences not significant.

Bonferroni Correction

With 9 independent tests conducted (1 Mann-Whitney U, 7 proportion tests, 1 chi-square), the Bonferroni-corrected significance threshold is Î± = 0.05 / 9 = 0.0056.

Tests surviving Bonferroni correction (p < 0.0056):

  • Task completion distribution: p = 0.000053 (significant)

Tests significant at Î± = 0.05 but not after correction:

  • Alignment score: p = 0.0058 (marginal)
  • Failed Rate: p = 0.0356 (marginal)

Non-significant tests:

  • Satisfaction Rate: p = 0.978 (both models 0%)
  • Dissatisfaction Rate: p = 0.580 (both models 0%)
  • Complete Rate: p = 0.298
  • Scope Expanded Rate: p = 0.153
  • One Shot Rate: p = 0.543
  • Good Execution Rate: p = 0.830

LLM-annotated dissatisfaction is extremely low for both models (<0.4%). Satisfaction and dissatisfaction differences between models are not statistically significant. The more direct accuracy signal from edit timeline analysis (§3) shows the same direction: Opus 4.5 rewrites previously-edited regions at 1.2× the rate of Opus 4.6 (17.7% vs 14.8%), with 42 user-directed corrections vs zero for Opus 4.6.

The invisible subagent: Opus 4.5 deploys far more total subagents (211 vs 16) but they serve different purposes. For Opus 4.6, 94% are lightweight, read-only Explore agents that quietly gather context before implementation begins. Opus 4.5 splits its subagents more evenly—37% are general-purpose implementation workers that visibly modify files. The models produce comparable output, but Opus 4.6 front-loads research while Opus 4.5 front-loads action.
Significance: Autonomy level (p=0.007, V=0.10) and one-shot rate (p=0.004, h=−0.16) significant at p<0.05 but not after Bonferroni correction.

Opus 4.6 sessions skew toward higher complexity: fewer trivial tasks (40% vs 47%) and proportionally more moderate tasks. This makes raw aggregate comparisons misleading—Opus 4.6 is tackling harder work on average.

Significance: Tool calls/task (p=0.000002, d=−0.29) and tools/file (p=0.000003, d=−0.18) survive Bonferroni correction—among the strongest signals in the study. Lines-added difference is also Bonferroni-significant.
The exploration–satisfaction tradeoff: Opus 4.6 uses 75% more tool calls per task yet produces 54% fewer lines of code. The extra activity is research, not output. This research correlates with higher alignment (+0.27) and completion (+3.7pp), but the marginal value of each additional tool call diminishes—180% more effort yields a small-effect improvement.

7. Planning: Correlation vs Causation

Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6
MetricDistribution4.54.6
Planning adoption rate
A
1.0%
B
4.0%
 15 tasks 4 tasks

Opus 4.5 rarely enters plan mode (1.0%, 15 of 1,517 tasks), while Opus 4.6 plans on 4.0% of tasks (4 of 99). The alignment benefit is substantial but based on very small samples: planned tasks score higher than unplanned tasks (4.5: 3.73 vs 2.95; 4.6: 3.50 vs 3.19).

42.9%
 6/141 3/7

Opus 4.5 rarely plans (1.4% overall). Opus 4.6 concentrates its planning on harder tasks: 42.9% of complex+ tasks and 3.8% of moderate tasks, with no planning for trivial or simple tasks. Neither model plans for trivial tasks.

Planning alignment by complexity bin
Opus 4.5Opus 4.6
ComplexityPlannedUnplannedΔPlannedUnplannedΔ
Trivial — (n=0)2.55 (n=767)— — (n=0)3.12 (n=41)—
Simple 3.00 (n=1)3.34 (n=304)−0.34 — (n=0)2.84 (n=25)—
Moderate 3.88 (n=8)3.30 (n=296)+0.57 4.00 (n=1)3.64 (n=25)+0.36
Complex+ 3.67 (n=6)3.51 (n=135)+0.16 3.33 (n=3)3.25 (n=4)+0.08
Insufficient evidence that planning is necessary: Although Opus 4.6 is the only model that plans, this data alone cannot establish that planning causes its better outcomes. For complex+ tasks, planned tasks score higher (5.00 vs 3.00), but this is based on just 1 scored planned task vs 4 scored unplanned tasks. Furthermore, only 5 of Opus 4.6’s 133 tasks use planning at all, making any causal claim extremely fragile. The same disposition that leads 4.6 to plan also leads it to explore more, use more subagents, and investigate before acting; planning may be a symptom of thoroughness rather than its mechanism. A controlled experiment (forcing planning on/off) would be needed to isolate the effect.

8. Context Window & Compaction

Claude Code compacts the conversation when the context window fills, summarizing earlier messages to free space. Community discussion has speculated that Opus 4.6’s higher token usage might lead to more frequent compaction. Our data tells a different story.

Neither model triggered any compaction events in the analyzed sessions. Both models had 0% compaction rates across all sessions (229 for Opus 4.5, 20 for Opus 4.6).

Outcome Impact

To measure whether compaction degrades quality, we split tasks in compacting sessions into pre- and post-compaction groups. A control group of non-compacting sessions uses a synthetic split at the same position to isolate position effects from compaction effects.

Metric (Opus 4.5)PrePostDeltaControl ΔCompaction Effect
Alignment score—————
Satisfaction rate—————
Completion rate—————
User correction rate—————

With zero compaction events for either model, no pre/post compaction outcome analysis is possible.

Opus 4.6 note: With only 2 compacting sessions (13 pre, 9 post tasks), the Opus 4.6 compaction effect cannot be reliably estimated. The compacting delta values are unavailable due to missing alignment/satisfaction data in the post-compaction sample.

Bottom line: Neither model triggered compaction events in the analyzed sessions, so no quality-impact analysis is available. The absence of compaction is consistent with sessions that stayed within context limits.

Opus 4.5 shows no warm-up effect: alignment stays flat at 2.85 between early and later tasks. Opus 4.6 improves from 2.95 to 3.06 in alignment and from 25.0% to 33.5% in completion rate, suggesting it benefits more from accumulated session context.

Research-first vs balanced: Opus 4.6 allocates 35% of tool calls to research (Read, Grep, Glob, Explore agents) vs 28% for Opus 4.5, with a correspondingly lower implementation ratio (17.5% vs 27.0%). Opus 4.6 also front-loads research more aggressively—59.3% of tasks show positive front-loading vs 54.3%. It investigates first, then implements in concentrated bursts.

Significance: Duration (p=0.015, d=−0.02) and iteration rate (p=0.018, V=0.10) significant at p<0.05 but not after Bonferroni correction. These effects are observational and confounded with task selection.

Both models degrade in longer sessions, but Opus 4.6 degrades more steeply: from 3.53 to 2.96 in alignment (−0.57) vs 2.93 to 2.85 (−0.08) for Opus 4.5. However, Opus 4.6 scores higher than Opus 4.5 in every session-length bucket—even in long sessions (2.96 vs 2.85). The steeper decline reflects 4.6’s higher baseline, not a crossover where 4.5 becomes preferable.

10. Model Profiles

Opus 4.5 — The Executor

Strategy: Act first, adjust as needed. Jumps to implementation with minimal upfront research.

Subagents: 37% general-purpose (implementation workers), 49% Explore. Primarily user-directed (55%).

Planning: Rarely uses planning mode (1.0%). Distributes research evenly through the task.

Strength: Efficient on trivial and simple tasks. Lower tool overhead. Stable performance across session lengths.

Risk: Higher failure rate on complex tasks. May miss edge cases that upfront research would catch.

Opus 4.6 — The Explorer

Strategy: Research first, implement in focused bursts. Front-loads investigation before touching files.

Subagents: 94% Explore (read-only research), 0% general-purpose. Evenly split autonomous/user-directed (50%).

Planning: Occasionally self-initiates planning (4.0% of tasks, 4 of 99).

Strength: Higher completion rate (+3.7pp), lower failure rate (−5.5pp). Best in short, focused sessions.

Risk: Higher tool overhead (75% more calls). Performance degrades in long sessions (−0.57 alignment over 9+ tasks).

Routing Recommendations

Task TypeRecommendedRationale
Trivial / simple tasksEither (slight cost edge: 4.5)Opus 4.5 is more cost-efficient, though 4.6 has a lower rewrite rate (14.8% vs 17.7% overall)
Complex / major tasksOpus 4.6Higher alignment, front-loaded research catches requirements that 4.5 may miss
RefactoringOpus 4.61.2× lower rewrite rate (14.8% vs 17.7%); research-first approach reduces rework
Investigation / researchOpus 4.6Natural fit with research-first strategy; autonomous Explore agents excel here
Long sessions (9+ tasks)Either4.6 degrades faster but still scores higher (2.96 vs 2.85); consider session-break discipline
Parallel executionOpus 4.6Actually backgrounds tasks; 4.5 spawns more agents but runs them sequentially

Data Cleaning Methodology

Task-level data cleaning applied four exclusion rules and four informational flags to canonical tasks before analysis. Exclusions remove tasks that do not represent genuine user-model interactions; flags annotate tasks with contextual metadata without removing them.

Exclusion Rules

RuleDescriptionOpus 4.5Opus 4.6
slash_commandTask prompt is a slash command (/command) or <command-name> tag — these invoke built-in features, not model reasoning——
system_continuationAutomatic continuations triggered by the system (e.g., context compaction boundaries, session resumptions) rather than deliberate user prompts——
empty_continuationBare acknowledgement prompts ("continue", "ok", "yes") with zero tool calls and <5s duration — the model produced no meaningful work——
no_response_interruptTasks where the model produced zero output (0 tool calls, 0 duration) before the session ended, typically user cancellations——

Informational Flags

These flags are preserved on included tasks for subgroup analysis but do not trigger exclusion:

  • meta — Task occurred within a meta-analysis session (e.g., this report's own development), where the model analyzed its own output
  • no_project — No project directory was associated with the session
  • interrupted — User interrupted the model mid-response (based on session end pattern)
  • post_compaction — Task occurred after a context compaction event in the same session, potentially with degraded context

Project Overlap & Sensitivity Analysis

A potential confound arises from unequal project coverage between models. To quantify this, a sensitivity analysis compares all statistical tests on the full dataset against a restricted subset containing only tasks from projects where both models were active. If results agree across both analyses, the project confound is unlikely to explain observed differences.

Each Claude Code session was segmented into tasks based on user-message boundaries and topic shifts. An LLM annotator classified each task for complexity, type, sentiment, completion status, and alignment score (1–5 scale). Behavioral metrics—subagent usage, planning, parallelization—were extracted from tool-call logs.

Edit timeline analysis tracked 2,948 Edit/Write tool calls across all sessions, building per-file content ownership maps to detect when a later edit’s old_string overlaps with an earlier edit’s new_string. Overlaps are detected via three tiers (exact match, containment at ≥30% ratio, and Jaccard line overlap) and classified by context (self-correction, error recovery, user-directed, iterative refinement). Edit metrics were joined with task classifications to compute complexity-binned accuracy rates (93% and 88% coverage for the two models).

Compaction analysis found 0 compact_boundary system messages across 0 compacting sessions, extracting trigger type, pre-compaction token count, and position. Outcome impact was measured by splitting tasks into pre/post groups at the first compaction timestamp, with a control group of non-compacting sessions split at the median compaction position to isolate position effects.

Statistical testing: 115 tests were conducted: chi-square (categorical), Mann-Whitney U (continuous), proportion tests (rates). Bonferroni-corrected threshold: p<0.00043. Eight findings survive correction: lines removed, lines per minute, tools per file, and five categorical distributions (task completion, scope management, iteration required, error recovery, communication quality). Significance notes appear inline in each section.

Complete statistical test results (115 tests)

Development Process

This analysis was developed iteratively. Several approaches were tried and abandoned when they proved unreliable:

Automated dissatisfaction detection (abandoned as primary signal): Initial LLM-based sentiment classification flagged 7–9% dissatisfaction for both models. LLM-agent audit of all 59 flagged cases revealed 73–93% false positive rates—the classifiers were fooled by task-coordination language (e.g., “fix” in subagent prompts). This approach was replaced by edit timeline analysis, which detects self-corrections mechanistically rather than through sentiment proxies.

LLM quality judgement (dropped): An LLM judge was asked to compare code quality between models. The results were unreliable—the judge lacked sufficient context to evaluate whether code met domain requirements, and produced confident but ungrounded assessments. This section was removed entirely rather than presented with caveats.

Refactoring routing recommendation (revised): Early signals suggested Opus 4.5 was better for refactoring, based on four false-positive dissatisfaction flags and small sample sizes. Sentiment detection and git retention both proved unreliable. Edit timeline analysis provided a direct mechanistic signal: tracking every edit across all sessions revealed that Opus 4.5 rewrites previously-edited regions at 1.2× the rate of Opus 4.6 (63.9% vs 51.7%), reversing the initial recommendation.

Limitations

Single user: All data comes from one developer’s workflow. Results may not generalize to other users, codebases, or task distributions.

Observational, not experimental: Tasks were not randomly assigned to models. Opus 4.6 was used later chronologically and on different (often harder) tasks, confounding model effects with task effects.

Complexity confound: Opus 4.6’s different complexity mix (37.3% moderate-and-above vs 32.6% for Opus 4.5) inflates its resource usage metrics and may suppress its satisfaction scores relative to what it would achieve on equivalent tasks.

Sample asymmetry: The 8.9:1 ratio (1,727 vs 193 tasks) means Opus 4.5 estimates have narrower confidence intervals. Effect sizes for Opus 4.6 are less precise.

LLM-in-the-loop analysis: All task classification, sentiment analysis, and dissatisfaction auditing was performed by LLM agents (Claude Haiku and Sonnet), with human review of outputs and skepticism-driven re-auditing. No classification was done by hand.

Claude Code Early Access Program · Single-user behavioral analysis · February 2026
